For theorems involving long arithmetic techniques, is there anything automation can do for us? I mean surely there's a much more simple proof than this right?

import Mathlib.Analysis.Complex.Polynomial.Basic

variable (D : Type) [DivisionRing D] [Algebra ℝ D]
  (a b c : ℝ) (k : Subalgebra ℝ D) (i : k) (j : D)

lemma linindepijk (this : a • a • (1 : D) + a • b • i.1 + a • c • j + (b • a • i.1 + -(b • b • (1 : D))
    + -(b • c • (i.1 * j))) + (c • a • j + c • b • (i.1 * j) + -(c • c • 1)) = -1):
  (a * a - b * b - c * c + 1) • 1 + (2 * a * b) • ↑i + (2 * a * c) • j = 0 := by
  simp only [smul_smul] at this
  rw [add_comm ((c * a) • j + (c * b) • (↑i * j)), ← add_assoc,
    ← add_assoc, ← add_assoc, ← add_assoc, add_assoc ((a * a) • 1),
    add_assoc ((a * a) • 1), add_assoc ((a * a) • 1), add_comm _ (- ((b * b) • 1)),
    ← add_assoc, ← neg_smul, ← add_smul, add_assoc ((a * a + -(b * b)) • 1),
    add_assoc ((a * a + -(b * b)) • 1), add_comm _ (- ((c * c) • 1)), ← add_assoc,
    ← neg_smul, ← add_smul, mul_comm b a, add_comm _ ((a * b) • i.1),
    ← add_assoc ((a * b) • i.1), ← add_smul, ← two_mul, ← mul_assoc 2 a b,
    ← add_assoc, ← add_assoc, mul_comm c a, add_assoc _ (-((b * c) • (↑i * j))),
    add_comm (-((b * c) • (↑i * j))) ((a * c) • j), ← add_assoc,
    add_assoc _ ((a * c) • j) ((a * c) • j), ← add_smul, ← two_mul, mul_comm c b,
    add_assoc _ _ ((b * c) • (i.1 * j)), neg_add_cancel, add_zero,
    eq_neg_iff_add_eq_zero, ← sub_eq_add_neg, ← sub_eq_add_neg] at this
  nth_rw 2 [← one_smul ℝ (1 : D)] at this
  rw [add_assoc, add_assoc, ← add_assoc _ _ (1 • 1), add_comm _ (1 • 1), ← add_assoc,
    ← add_smul, ← add_assoc, ← mul_assoc] at this
  exact this

lemma linindepijk (this : a • a • (1 : D) + a • b • i.1 + a • c • j + (b • a • i.1 + -(b • b • (1 : D))
    + -(b • c • (i.1 * j))) + (c • a • j + c • b • (i.1 * j) + -(c • c • 1)) = -1) :
  (a * a - b * b - c * c + 1) • 1 + (2 * a * b) • ↑i + (2 * a * c) • j = 0 := by
  rw [eq_neg_iff_add_eq_zero] at this
  rw [← this]
  simp only [add_smul, sub_smul, one_smul, two_mul, add_mul, ← mul_smul]
  ring_nf
  abel

It seems that your problem is a more complex version of the following toy example:

import Mathlib.Tactic

variable
  (R : Type) [CommRing R]
  (M : Type) [AddCommGroup M] [Module R M]
  (r s t u v : R) (m n p : M)

example (h : r • m + s • n - t • m + s • n = u • p + v • n) :
    (r - t) • m - u • p + (2 * s) • n = v • n := by
  sorry

It would be nice to have a one-liner to do all these sorts of things. In Andrew's proof he's lucky that he can use rw [\l this] to do the substitution (as opposed to needing a times it or whatever; he's basically observing that linear_combination this would work if D were commutative). In practice linarith and polyrith are the two tactics we have to do this kind of stuff and neither work here.
@Heather Macbeth is this what the module tactic is supposed to do?

Andrew Yang said:

    + -(b • c • (i.1 * j))) + (c • a • j + c • b • (i.1 * j) + -(c • c • 1)) = -1) :
  (a * a - b * b - c * c + 1) • 1 + (2 * a * b) • ↑i + (2 * a * c) • j = 0 := by
  rw [eq_neg_iff_add_eq_zero] at this
  rw [← this]
  simp only [add_smul, sub_smul, one_smul, two_mul, add_mul, ← mul_smul]
  ring_nf
  abel

thanks!

You can use linear_combination with module as the normalization tactic.

lemma linindepijk (this : a • a • (1 : D) + a • b • i.1 + a • c • j + (b • a • i.1 + -(b • b • (1 : D))
    + -(b • c • (i.1 * j))) + (c • a • j + c • b • (i.1 * j) + -(c • c • 1)) = -1):
  (a * a - b * b - c * c + 1) • 1 + (2 * a * b) • ↑i + (2 * a * c) • j = 0 := by
  linear_combination (norm := module) this
